criterias.name: Favicon
criterias.description:
Make sure your website has a favicon bound to the 
    brand. Favicon is a tiny image displayed next to the website's URL in the browser 
    address field. It helps to distinguish your website from other websites and increase the brand awareness.

criterias.name: Frames
criterias.description:
Never use frames to display the content of the page. 
    A frame is a separate HTML page that needs to have its own Title, Description and keywords. 
    Typically, a frame based website would get indexed more slowly and often not completely.

criterias.name: Flash
criterias.description:
It's advised not to overuse Flash files with the website 
    that is being promoted or avoid using these at all. Search engines read textual information 
    correctly while Flash content may be indexed incorrectly. It is advised to use Flash for 
    decoration purposes only while keep the textual content in the HTML section.

criterias.name: Mirror
criterias.description:
Check the "www.domain.com" mirror in your website's 
    URL "domain.com". If you have not used the mirror, make the 301 redirect to the preferred 
    version of the website. Otherwise search engines may distinguish and index several versions 
    of the same page

criterias.name: Robots.txt file
criterias.description:
Robots.txt file lists the URLs that may be indexed 
    by the search engines or are prohibited from indexing. The file also lists the website's 
    mirror URL and the sitemap URL.

criterias.name: XML sitemap
criterias.description:
Having a sitemap helps search engine bots to index 
    the website but must be specified in the Google Search Console. You may generate sitemaps f
    or URLs, images, videos, news and mobile content.

criterias.name: Safe browsing
criterias.description:
Try to avoid fishing and badware for your 
    website. You may secure website's work using Google's safe browsing.

criterias.name: Rel="canonical" attribute
criterias.description:
A rel="canonical" is an HTML element that helps 
    webmasters prevent duplicate content issues by specifying the "canonical" or "preferred" 
    version of a web page as part of search engine optimization. It is described in RFC 6596, 
    which went live in April 2012

criterias.name: W3C HTML validation
criterias.description:
A page that passes W3C HTML validity test opens 
    and is displayed correctly at any device. W3C HTML validity is a positive factor for 
    the page's ranking and must be checked after any change in the website code or content.
